perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS, PCQ and ABW have executed that certain Co-Branding Agreement dated October 11, 1996, as amended on December 10, 1996 (as so amended, the "Agreement");
perturbation.changed_text:
WHEREAS, PCQ and ABW have executed that certain Co-Branding Agreement dated October 11, 1996, as amended on December 10, 1996 (as so amended, the "Agreement");
WHEREAS, both parties agree to resolve any dispute under conditions where each party is responsible for its legal fees. This clause is non-binding and is subject to future negotation.
perturbation.explanation: Moving a clause related to dispute resolution and legal fees to the 'WHEREAS' section creates a contradiction. The 'WHEREAS' section is typically introductory and non-binding. Placing a statement about legal fees there makes it ambiguous whether it's an enforceable term, especially since it is indicated as non-binding and open for future negotiation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clarity and certainty in contractual terms; ambiguity in fee-shifting arrangements can lead to disputes.

perturbation.original_text: To the extent, if any, that provision of this Agreement conflicts with or differs from any provision of the Agreement, such provision of this Second Amendment shall prevail and govern for all purposes and in all respects.
perturbation.changed_text:
To the extent, if any, that provision of this Agreement conflicts with or differs from any provision of the Agreement, such provision of this Second Amendment shall prevail and govern for all purposes and in all respects.
However, in instances of disagreement regarding trademarks, logos or other marketing materials each part will come to a mutual, non-binding resolution.
perturbation.explanation: Adding a clause about trademarks and logos each part will come to a mutual, non-binding resolution creates a conflict with the first statement that states one amendment will have governance over all conflicts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clarity and certainty in contractual terms; ambiguity in fee-shifting arrangements can lead to disputes.
